signature.name: HTML5 Variant 1
signature.note:
HTML 5 does not explicitly define the HTML version or any Document Type Definition (DTD) within the DOCTYPE tag. An HTML5 DOCTYPE tag may contain an obsolete permitted DOCTYPE string, however this is discouraged. As such the present signature does not cover identification of an HTML5 document that includes this obsolete permitted DOCTYPE string. This signature may be subject to further revision as, at the time of writing, development on the HTML5 standard is still ongoing.
Variant 1: <!(DOCTYPE|doctype){0-4}(HTML|html)>

signature.name: HTML5 Variant 2
signature.note: BOF: <!(DOCTYPE|doctype){0-4}(HTML|html){0-4}{SYSTEM|system){0-4}('|")about:legacy-compat('|")>

details.dc:description: The HyperText Markup Language (HTML) is a markup language designed for the rendering of information via a web browser. It was originally defined as a highly simplified subset of SGML, but is now an international standard, and is maintained by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C). A HTML document consists of nested elements, each of which may have attributes and content. It begins with an HTML Document Type declaration. HTML 5 does not explicitly define the HTML version or any Document Type Definition (DTD) within the DOCTYPE tag.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives
record_metadata.dc:description: This signature may be subject to further revision as, at the time of writing, development on the HTML5 standard is still ongoing.

details.dc:description: When a previously saved Word document is opened for editing, for printing, or for review, Word creates a temporary file that has a .doc file name extension. This file name extension begins with a tilde (~) that is followed by a dollar sign ($) that is followed by the remainder of the original file name. This temporary file holds the logon name of person who opens the file. This temporary file is called the "owner file."

signature.name: PDF/A-2A
signature.note: BOF: %PDF1.(0-7) VAR: Identifies the byte sequence which equals - xmlns:pdfaid="http://www.aiim.org/pdfa/ns/id/ which is the PDF/A identification namespace within the PDF/A meta-data, followed by <pdfaid:part>2<pdfaid:part> and <pdfaid:conformance>A<pdfaid:conformance>, which are the two mandatory elements and values for PDF/A. See ISO 19005-2:2011 for further information.

details.dc:description: The Portable Document Format/Archive is a format designed for long term preservation by Adobe Systems. PDF/A is an ISO standardised version of PDF, with all of the features from PDF that would impede long term preservation removed. A major principle of PDF/A is that it is self contained and not reliant on externalities thus all font and colour information is encoded into the file. PDF/A files are larger than other types of PDF files due to the need for embedded information. PDF/A2 supports three levels of compliance: PDF/A-2a (Accessible), PDF/A-2b (Basic). and PDF/A-2u (Unicode). The PDF/A-2 standard is a constrained subset of ISO 32000-1 (PDF 1.7), which includes PDF 1.0-1.7 and is defined by ISO 19005-2:2011, which has the formal name 'Document management – Electronic document file format for long-term preservation – Part 2: Use of ISO 32000-1 (PDF/A-2)'.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

See ISO 19005-2:2011 for further information.

signature.name: PDF/A-3A
signature.note: BOF: %PDF1.(0-7) VAR: Identifies the byte sequence which equals - xmlns:pdfaid="http://www.aiim.org/pdfa/ns/id/ which is the PDF/A identification namespace within the PDF/A meta-data, followed by <pdfaid:part>3<pdfaid:part> and <pdfaid:conformance>A<pdfaid:conformance>, which are the two mandatory elements and values for PDF/A. See ISO 19005-3:2012 for further information.

details.dc:description: The Portable Document Format/Archive is a format designed for long term preservation by Adobe Systems. PDF/A is an ISO standardised version of PDF, with all of the features from PDF that would impede long term preservation removed. A major principle of PDF/A is that it is self contained and not reliant on externalities thus all font and colour information is encoded into the file. PDF/A files are larger than other types of PDF files due to the need for embedded information. PDF/A3 supports three levels of compliance: PDF/A-3a (Accessible), PDF/A-3b (Basic). and PDF/A-3u (Unicode). The PDF/A-2 standard is a constrained subset of ISO 32000-1 (PDF 1.7), which includes PDF 1.0-1.7 and is defined by ISO 19005-3:2012, which has the formal name 'Document management - Electronic document file format for long-term preservation - Part 3: Use of ISO 32000-1 with support for embedded files (PDF/A-3)'. The primary new feature in PDF/A-3 is the ability to embed any source format within a PDF/A file.

format.name: Acrobat PDF/X - Portable Document Format - Exchange PDF/X-4

signature.name: PDF/X-4
signature.note: BOF: %PDF-1.[0-7] - specification is based on PDF1.6, however the specification doesn't specifically preclude other versions. We have seen and produced samples with PDF value not 1.6, so we are including all possible values. VAR: <pdfxid:GTS_PDFXVersion>PDF/X-4</pdfxid:GTS_PDFXVersion>

details.dc:description: PDF/X was developed by the Committee for Graphics Arts Technologies Standards (CGATS) and Adobe. This 'exchange standard' format is based on Adobe's PDF specification and includes additional notes specifically to facilitate graphics exchange. PDF/X is a subset of the PDF specification, and is an application standard as well as a file format standard. There are several versions of the standard, which address specific issues.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

details.dc:description:
A Microsoft Office - Word, Excel, or PowerPoint document, that has been encrypted.
The encrypted document conforms to the MS-OFFCRYPTO specification, as found here: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc313071(v=office.12).aspx
The document is an OLE2 compound that contains a number of files:
EncryptionInfo - This file contains information used by the Office-compatible application to decrypt the encrypted package. There are multiple variants of this file, as described in 2.3.4.5, and 2.3.4.6 of the format specification.
EncryptedPackage - This file contains the whole of the encrypted document.
DataSpaces folder (and sub-files) - This structure associates protected content with data space definitions. The data space definition, in turn, describes the series of transforms that must be applied to that protected content to restore it to its original form.
Since the method of identifying and distinguishing specific types of OOXML documents relies on seeking and analysing specific elements within the document, and in the case of encryption this information is obfuscated, it does not currently seem possible to determine with any specificity whether an encrypted file is either an Excel, Word, or PowerPoint document, apart from the file extension.

signature.name: ATCO-CIF
signature.note: BOF: ATCO-CIF

details.dc:description: ATCO-CIF is a file format for interchange of bus timetable information, primarily between the Department for Transport and service providers.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: TransXchange
signature.note: BOF: <?xml version="1.0"{0-64}<TransXChange xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.transxchange.org.uk/

details.dc:description: TransXChange is a UK national data standard for the exchange of bus route and timetable information. The standard is sponsored by the UK Department for Transport and is mandated by the Vehicle Operating Services Agency (VOSA) for the electronic registration of UK bus services with Traffic Area Offices (TAO) and Local Authorities. It is a subset of XML.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

details.dc:description: The Wireless Application Protocol Bitmap format, or Wireless Bitmap, is a monochrome image format optimised for use on the mobile web.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives
record_metadata.dc:description:
The format structure is as follows: The first two bytes are both '00'. The next two bytes represent the width, then height of the image in pixels. The remaining bytes represent the image data. Further information regarding the format can be found on the Wikipedia page: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wireless_Application_Protocol_Bitmap_Format The file format specification is available here: http://web.archive.org/web/20010605024138/http://www.wapforum.org/what/technical/SPEC-WAESpec-19990524.pdf
It is not possible to create a strong binary signature for this format, since the only constant bytes are the first two, both '00', which would cause an identification clash with many other formats.

signature.name: LPK
signature.note: BOF: LPK License Package…

details.dc:description: A License Package file is generated by Visual Basic tools to accompany ActiveX controls where delivered via a website. The file is located server-side, and is required to ensure the ActiveX controls work correctly. They are generated with the Visual Basic 'LPK_Tool.exe' program file.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: Vivo Active V1
signature.note: BOF offset 3 ..Version:Vivo/1.00

signature.name: Vivo Active V2
signature.note: BOF offset 3 ..Version:Vivo/2.00

details.dc:description: VivoActive is an audio/video format created by Vivo Software, acquired by RealNetworks in 1997. It uses H.263 video and G.723 ADPCM audio. VivoActive uses inter-frame coding, but does not insert any key frames, except at the beginning of the clip, which effectively disables the possibility of seeking to specific locations in the stream. The VivoActive technology was integrated to the RealMedia, the .viv format was replaced by .rm (RealMedia).

signature.name: Apple Double Resource Fork (v2)
signature.note: BOF: "…….." 4 byte AppleDouble Magic Number, then 4 byte version number

details.dc:description:
The resource fork is a construct of the Mac OS operating system used to store structured data in a file, alongside unstructured data stored within the data fork. The format specification is available here: http://support.apple.com/kb/TA32537?viewlocale=en_US
The format lacks an extension, and is instead represented by a file name consisting of ._<filename resource fork belongs to>
details.dc:creator: Apple Computer, Inc.

details.dc:description: Standard flowgram format (SFF) is a binary file format used to encode results of pyrosequencing from the 454 Life Sciences platform for high-throughput sequencing.

signature.name: SWF 8
signature.note: Header (FWS then version number) and end tag (..)

signature.name: SWF 8 - zlib compressed
signature.note: Header (CWS then version number)

details.dc:description: The Adobe Flash format, SWF, previously known as Shockwave Flash or Macromedia Shockwave Flash, and alternatively known as the Small Web Format, is a file format primarily designed for creating interactive multimedia applications. The format iterates rapidly, often in line with new releases of Adobe Flash or Adobe Air. Prior to version 6 all SWF files were uncompressed, however version 6 introduced the option of using zlib compression. Version 13 introduced the option of using LZMA compression.
details.dc:creator: Adobe Systems Incorporated

signature.name: QIC
signature.note: BOF: VTBL{54}version number(q.= Win 95|AS=Win98/ME){66}..

details.dc:description: Quarter Inch Cartridge tape is a magnetic tape data storage format. The '.qic' software format is based on the QIC113 specification: http://www.qic.org/html/standards/11x.x/qic113g.pdf and conforming files were generated by Microsoft 9x operating systems with the native MSBackup.exe utility.

details.dc:description: Part of the PostScript Type 1 font format family. On Windows, Type 1 fonts consist of a PostScript Font Binary (.PFB) file, plus a corresponding PostScript Font Metrics (.PFM) file. (Some very old Type 1 fonts may ship with a .PFB, .AFM, and .INF file. Installing such fonts will create a .PFM file from the .AFM and .INF files.)

signature.name: Broad Band eBook (lrf)
signature.note: BOF: L.R.F…

details.dc:description: Broad Band eBook (BBeB) is a proprietary e-book format created by Sony and Canon for Sony e-book readers. The LRF variant is a compiled, unencrypted version of an LRS file. Sony discontinued development of BBeB in 2010, in favour of the EPUB format.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: Polynomial Texture Map
signature.note: BOF: PTM_1.2.PTM_FORMAT_

details.dc:description: Developed by Hewlett Packard, Polynomial texture maps (PTMs) are an extension to conventional texture maps that allow enhanced image quality. As opposed to storing a color per pixel, these PTM’s store second-order bi-quadratic polynomial coefficients per pixel. These polynomials model the changes that appear to a pixel color based on either light source position or viewing direction.
details.dc:creator: Hewlett Packard Company

signature.name: Adobe Printer Font Binary
signature.note: BOF: €.{4}%!PS-AdobeFont-1.0

details.dc:description: Printer Font Binary (.pfb) is a type 1 font made by Adobe and other companies.They are encrypted and compressed and also allow for hints, which improve the appearance of text at 300 dpi and lower resolutions. With Adobe Type Manager, Type 1 fonts can also be used on non-PostScript printers. However, Mac OS X and Windows, starting with Windows 2000, natively support Type 1 fonts, and Adobe Type Manager is not required. Research done by The National Archives.

signature.name: BWAVE Generic 2
signature.note: RIFF header, WAVE ID, BEXT chunk (Version=2)

details.dc:description: Broadcast WAVE is a chunk-based audio format developed by the European Broadcasting Union, and based on the Microsoft WAVE format, which is in turn based on the generic Resource Interchange File Format (RIFF) specification developed by Microsoft and IBM. Structurally, a BWAVE file is composed of a number of chunks, each comprising a four character code chunk identifier, the chunk size, and the chunk data. It comprises a RIFF header with a WAVE data type identifier, followed by a series of chunks. Every file must include a Broadcast Audio Extension chunk, containing metadata required for exchange of information between broadcasters, a Format chunk, which describes the format of the audio data, and a Data chunk, containing the audio data itself. BWAVE files which contain MPEG-encoded audio data must also include a Fact chunk, containing file-dependent information about the audio data, and an MPEG Audio Extension chunk, containing extra information required to describe the MPEG encoding. A BWAVE identified as generic by DROID likely uses an encoding format unknown to PRONOM, or perhaps a structural difference, and users are encouraged to let the PRONOM team know should this occur.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: JNG
signature.note: BOF ‹JNG........JHDR EOF IEND®B`‚

details.dc:description: JPEG Network Graphics (JNG) is a JPEG-based graphics file format which is closely related to PNG: it uses the PNG file structure (with a different signature) as a container format to wrap JPEG encoded image data. JNG was created as an adjunct to the MNG animation format, but may be used as a stand-alone format. JNG files embed an 8-bit or 12-bit JPEG datastream in order to store color data, and may embed another datastream (1, 2, 4, 8, 16 bit PNG, or 8 bit JPEG grayscale image) for transparency information. However, a JNG may contain two separate JPEG datastreams for color information (one eight-bit and one twelve-bit) to permit decoders that are unable to (or do not wish to) handle twelve-bit datastreams to display the eight-bit datastream instead, if one is present.

signature.name: Adobe Illustrator 8.0
signature.note: The first line of the file declares that the file contains a Postscript program and identifies the version of the Document Structuring Conventions to which the document conforms as 3.0. The comment “%AI5_FileFormat 4” indicates that this is a version 8.0 Adobe Illustrator file.

details.dc:description: The documents (files) created by Adobe Illustrator are PostScript language documents. A PostScript language document description that minimally conforms to the Document Structuring Conventions has two main parts: a prolog and a script. The prolog encapsulates information needed by other programs to interpret the file. The script describes the graphic elements on the page.
details.dc:creator: Adobe Systems Incorporated

record_metadata.dc:creator: Georgia Tech Research Institute / Georgia Tech Research Institute

details.dc:description: The documents (files) created by Adobe Illustrator are PostScript language documents. A PostScript language document description that minimally conforms to the Document Structuring Conventions has two main parts: a prolog and a script. The prolog encapsulates information needed by other programs to interpret the file. The script describes the graphic elements on the page. Beginning with version 9, the Adobe Illustrated ai file format included both a pdf copy of the illustration and a postscript copy.

signature.name: WebP Lossy
signature.note: RIFF{4}WEBPVP8

details.dc:description: WebP is a raster image format developed by Google that uses the Resource Interchange File Format as a container. WebP's lossy compression algorithm is based on the intra-frame coding of the VP8 video format.
details.dc:creator: Google

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: WebP Lossless
signature.note: RIFF{4}WEBPVP8L

details.dc:description: WebP is a raster image format developed by Google that uses the Resource Interchange File Format as a container. WebP’s lossless compression uses advanced techniques such as dedicated entropy codes for different color channels, exploiting 2D locality of backward reference distances and a color cache of recently used colors. This complements basic techniques such as dictionary coding, Huffman coding and color indexing transform.
details.dc:creator: Google

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: WebP Extended
signature.note: RIFF{4}WEBPVP8X

details.dc:description: WebP is a raster image format developed by Google that uses the Resource Interchange File Format as a container. The extended version of the format allows for alternative colour profiles and animation.
details.dc:creator: Google

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: Matroska Video
signature.note: 0x1A45DFA3(EBML-Level 0 element), {0-32}, 0x428288(DocType element), string=matroska, 0x4287(DocTypeVersion element). The specification allows for ASCII text before the EBML header and considers the level 0 EBML header element to be the beginning of the EBML document. For now this signature is offset to 1024 bytes to allow for some ASCII text to precede the header, but to assume the EBML header of a Matroska multimedia format will begin near the beginning of the file and to mitigate against wasteful processing of large files that are not Matroska multimedia.

details.dc:description:
The Matroska Multimedia Container is an open standard free container format, based on the Extensible Binary Meta Language (EBML). Matroska file extensions are .MKV for video (with subtitles and audio), .MK3D for stereoscopic video, .MKA for audio-only files, and .MKS for subtitles only. The Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) Working Group: Codec Encoding for LossLess Archiving and Realtime transmission (cellar) is tasked with the standardisation of Matroska.
The EBML specifications are work-in-progress, and can be found here: https://github.com/Matroska-Org/ebml-specification/blob/master/specification.markdown

example_file.dc:title: Matroska Test Suite - Wave 1
example_file.dc:description: A set of 8 files meant to cover the basic features a player should support to be considered a good Matroska player.

format.name: Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine File Format

signature.name: DICOM
signature.note: 128 0x00 bytes, followed by 'DICM' ASCII string. This could also be expessed as just 'DICM', with a 128 byte offset, however including the 00 bytes strengthens the signature.

details.dc:description: DICOM (Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine) is a standard for handling, storing, printing, and transmitting information in medical imaging. It includes a file format definition and a network communications protocol. The communication protocol is an application protocol that uses TCP/IP to communicate between systems. DICOM files can be exchanged between two entities that are capable of receiving image and patient data in DICOM format. The National Electrical Manufacturers Association (NEMA) holds the copyright to this standard. It was developed by the DICOM Standards Committee, whose members are also partly members of NEMA.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Tessella / Tessella

signature.name: GraphPad Prism 1-3
signature.note: BOF: PCFFGRAF

details.dc:description: GraphPad Prism is a scientific graphing and analysis application which organises, analyses and graphs repeated experiments, picks appropriate statistical tests, and interprets the results.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Tessella / Tessella

signature.name: GraphPad Prism 4
signature.note: BOF: PCFFGRA4

details.dc:description: GraphPad Prism is a scientific graphing and analysis application which organises, analyses and graphs repeated experiments, picks appropriate statistical tests, and interprets the results.

signature.name: Image Cytometry Standard 1.0
signature.note: BOF: <horizontal tab><line feed>ics_version.1.0

details.dc:description: The Image Cytometry Standard (ICS) is a digital multidimensional image file format used in life sciences microscopy. It stores not only the image data, but also the microscopic parameters describing the optics during the acquisition. Version 1 of the format holds just the metadata and a pointer to a corresponding .ids file which contains the pixel data.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Tessella / Tessella

signature.name: Image Cytometry Standard 2.0
signature.note: BOF: <horizontal tab><line feed>ics_version.2.0

details.dc:description: The Image Cytometry Standard (ICS) is a digital multidimensional image file format used in life sciences microscopy. It stores not only the image data, but also the microscopic parameters describing the optics during the acquisition. Version 2 of the format contains both the metadata and pixel data.

details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

signature.name: Windows Media Metafile
signature.note: <(asx|ASX) (version|VERSION){0-1}={0-3}3{0-64}>

details.dc:description: A media metafile is a file that contains information about other files. A metafile can be used to list a group of media content files that are to be played in order. The .wax metafile references Windows Media files with .asf, .wma, or .wax file name extensions. The .wvx metafile references Windows Media files with .wma, .wmv, .wvx, or .wax file name extensions. The asx metafile references Windows Media files with .wma, .wax, .wmv, .wvx, .asf, or .asx file name extensions.
details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives
record_metadata.dc:description: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd564665(v=vs.85).aspx

signature.name: MPEG-2 Transport Stream
signature.note: Packets of 188 bytes each, each packet beginning with 0x47. This signature may be strengthened with a better understanding of the make-up of these packets.

details.dc:description: MPEG-2 is a lossy compression standard (an improvement and expansion of the MPEG-1 standard) designed for the generic coding of video and audio and intended to cover a wide scope of application, including: video production, broadcast and editing. Streams are at potentially higher bitrates than MPEG-1 but more efficient compression making it suited to High Definition video. MPEG-2 Video supports both 'progressive' and 'interlaced' frame video. An MPEG-2 'Transport' stream file (TS) file (*.ts, *.m2ts) is designed for low-latency, real-time transmission and is used in broadcasting. It can contain multiple programmes, not necessarily intended for synchronised playback. TS incorporates features that can allow flexible access to and playback of stream content.

details.dc:description: REDCODE RAW (R3D) is a proprietary multimedia audio/video file format owned by the Red Digital Cinema Camera Company and featuring lossy compression for video contents and lossless for audio contents. It is used as native recording format of Red digital cameras and recorded on proprietary Hard Disk Drives, CompactFlash cards or SSD drives, but can be extracted from there and be trivially handled in any file-based audio/video, IT or home environments.

For JPEG extended range) is a still-image compression standard and file format for continuous tone photographic images, based on technology originally developed and patented by Microsoft under the name HD Photo (formerly Windows Media Photo). It supports both lossy and lossless compression.

details.dc:description: Radiance defined an image format for storing HDR images, now described as RGBE image format. RGBE stores pixels as one byte each for RGB (red, green, and blue) values with a one byte shared exponent. Thus it stores four bytes per pixel.

details.dc:description: From Microsoft Office 2007 onwards, the core output format of MS Excel has been based on the Office Open XML (OOXML) file format. The ISO standard for OOXML is ISO/IEC DIS 29500. An OOXML file format consists of a compressed zip archive that is designated according to which file type it is. Further detail on OOXML can be found within fmt/189 - Microsoft Office Open XML.

details.dc:description: Apple Lossless, also known as Apple Lossless Audio Codec (ALAC), or Apple Lossless Encoder (ALE), is an audio codec developed by Apple Inc. for lossless data compression of digital music. Apple Lossless data is stored within an MP4 container with the filename extension .m4a.

details.dc:description: From Microsoft Office 2007 onwards, the core output format of MS Word has been based on the Office Open XML (OOXML) file format. The ISO standard for OOXML is ISO/IEC DIS 29500. An OOXML file format consists of a compressed zip archive that is designated according to which file type it is. Further detail on OOXML can be found within fmt/189 - Microsoft Office Open XML.
details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

details.dc:description: SAS (Statistical Analysis System) is a statistical analysis software suite developed by SAS Institute. details.dc:description: This format is identifiable via a container signature in DROID 6 and later. Some Word documents from this era lack an internal [CompObj] stream, which is used by fmt/39 and fmt/40 to distinguish between Word files generated in Microsoft Office 6.0/95, and 97-2003. Since compatible files created by certain software lack this stream (potentially including, but not necessarily limited to Apple Pages), this additional identifying record is required to avoid the limiting identification of OLE2.

signature.note: The byte at position 0x40-43 represent four potential values for data block sizes and 0x44-47 represent 3 potential tag sizes in bytes (there is a possiblity there are additional values for these sequences which may require future adjustment to the signature) 0x50 defines the disk encoding. Further information is found here: http://68kmla.org/wiki/index.php/DiskCopy_4.2_format_specification

signature.name: MPEG-2 Elementary Stream
signature.note: BOF: ...³

details.dc:description: MPEG-2 is a lossy compression standard (an improvement and expansion of the MPEG-1 standard) designed for the generic coding of video and audio and intended to cover a wide scope of application, including: video production, broadcast and editing. Streams are at potentially higher bitrates than MPEG-1 but more efficient compression making it suited to High Definition video. MPEG-2 Video supports both 'progressive' and 'interlaced' frame video. An MPG2 ‘Elementary’ stream (ES) file (*.m2v) contains either a single video or audio stream. ES files are generally intended for video editing or other intermediate use, where separate audio content can be ultimately blended ('interleaved' or ‘muxed’) with a video stream to produce an output file containing both audio and video for synchronised playback.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: Epson RAW Image Format
signature.note: The first byte sequence is the same BOF as TIFF/EP files. The remaining sequence is specific to the Epson R-D1 camera.

details.dc:description: This format is the RAW image format used in Epsom cameras. RAW format images contain all the data that is taken directly from the camera's image sensor before the software in the camera applies things like white balance, sharpening etc. Storing photographs in a camera's RAW format allows you to alter those settings after the photograph has been taken.
details.dc:creator: Epson America Inc.

details.dc:description: NSIS (Nullsoft Scriptable Install System) is an open source system to create Windows installers. NSIS is script-based and although it has regular and well defined syntax, there are no magic numbers or header sequences. As such, there is no current means to identify a file as NSIS by binary sequence alone, so identification of this format is by extension only.

signature.name: Media View Pro
signature.note: BOF: 030i (offset 4) EOF: Svar {8-34} 030i (offset 8)

details.dc:description: Proprietary cataloguing program to manage photo and video assets.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

details.dc:description: MPEG-1 is a lossy compression standard for video and audio, intended for use in Digital Storage Media (DSM) such as VideoCD and DVD (at the same encoding standard as VCD). It is designed to handle video frame-sizes of 352 x 288px, at a frame-rate of 25 frames per second (PAL) and a data rate of around 1.2Mbits/s; audio: up to 320 kbits/s (MPEG-1 Audio Layer III, *.mp3). MPEG-1 supports random access to stream content on playback. MPEG-1 Video supports only 'progressive' frame video. MPEG-1 compression can be relatively inefficient by modern standards. An MPG-1 ‘Elementary’ stream (ES) file (*.m1v) contains either a single video or audio stream (e.g. *.mp3). ES files are generally intended for video editing or other intermediate use, where separate audio content can be ultimately blended ('interleaved' or ‘muxed’) with a video stream to produce an output file containing both audio and video for synchronised playback.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: INTERLIS 2.3 Transfer File
signature.note: BOF: <?xml version=('|")1.0('|") encoding=('|")UTF-8('|"){0-2}?>{0-256}<TRANSFER xmlns=('|")http://www.interlis.ch/INTERLIS2.3('|")

details.dc:description: INTERLIS is a description and transfer mechanism for spatial data. INTERLIS 2 Transfer files are XML files that contain data, e.g. geodata, which is structured according to certain rules. These rules are described in another file (or multiple files) called a model file.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Swiss Federal Office of Topography / Federal Office of Topography
record_metadata.dc:description: http://www.interlis.ch

signature.name: INTERLIS 2.3 Model File
signature.note: BOF (Max Offset 4096): INTERLIS 2.3;.{1024}MODEL{1-64}AT{1-64}VERSION

details.dc:description: INTERLIS is a description and transfer mechanism for spatial data. INTERLIS 2 Model files contain the the geodata and can be converted to XML Schema (XSD) files (by using a software called INTERLIS compiler). Such models are described using a Modula-like language, which can be thought of as a superset of UML.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Swiss Federal Office of Topography / Federal Office of Topography

details.dc:description: Cypher is a declarative graph query language for the open source graph database, Neo4j. Although it has regular and well defined syntax, there are no magic numbers or header sequences. As such, there is no current means to identify a file as CQL by binary sequence alone, so identification of this format is by extension only.

details.dc:description: The Industry Foundation Classes (IFC) data model is intended to describe building and construction industry data. It is a platform neutral, open file format specification that is not controlled by a single vendor or group of vendors. It is an object-based file format with a data model developed by buildingSMART (formerly the International Alliance for Interoperability, IAI) to facilitate interoperability in the architecture, engineering and construction (AEC) industry, and is a commonly used collaboration format in Building information modeling (BIM) based projects.

details.dc:description: PKCS is a group of public-key cryptography standards devised and published by RSA Security Inc, starting in the early 1990s. PKCS #7 describes a general syntax for data that may have cryptography applied to it, such as digital signatures and digital envelopes. P7M is the format that implements this standard.

details.dc:description: A thumbs.db file is generated automatically within Microsoft Windows environments (although the automatic creation behaviour can be turned off). It is generally a hidden system file and its purpose is to hold thumbnail images of any images stored within a given folder. This format is based on the OLE2 Compound Document Format and can be identified in DROID 6 and later via a container signature. Structurally it holds a Catalog file that indexes the thumbnails, and a file per image that contains the image data in a JPEG format with additional data preceeding the image data. At this time the signature is the result of reverse engineering work conducted by Ross Spencer, Richard Lehane and others. The Catalog file consists of a 4 byte opening sequence that appears to act as an identifier and database version number, followed by two bytes indicating the number of images within the thumbs.db file, followed by information relating to the resolution of the images. This signature is likely to be improved with further research and a better understanding of the format structure. This particular format is known to be produced in Windows XP environments, but may also apply to other Windows operating systems. Later thumbs.db files hold a different structure which cannot yet be suitably represented within a DROID container signature.
details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

details.dc:description: Better Portable Graphics (BPG) is a raster image format created by Fabrice Bellard. It is intended as a compression-efficient alternative to the JPEG image format. It is based on the intra-frame encoding of the High Efficiency Video Coding (HEVC) video compression standard, and various metadata profiles (such as EXIF, ICC profile, XMP) are supported.

details.dc:description: The Executable and Linkable Format (ELF) was developed by Unix System Laboratories and is the standard binary format for executables, object code, shared libraries and core dumps in Unix and Unix-like systems running x86 architecture. Generally within Unix and Unix-like systems, ELF files generally do not have a format extension, however some ELF files may be found with a .elf or .o extension

details.dc:description: Dalvik is the process virtual machine in Google's Android operating system, which executes applications written for Android. Programs are commonly written in Java and compiled to bytecode for the Java virtual machine, which is then translated to Dalvik bytecode and stored in .dex (Dalvik EXecutable) and .odex (Optimized Dalvik EXecutable) files.

signature.name: BWAVE PCM 0
signature.note: RIFF header, WAVE ID, BEXT chunk (Version=0), Format chunk

signature.name: BWAVE PCM 0 variant
signature.note: RIFF header, WAVE ID, Format chunk, BEXT chunk (Version=0)

details.dc:description: Broadcast WAVE is a chunk-based audio format developed by the European Broadcasting Union, and based on the Microsoft WAVE format, which is in turn based on the generic Resource Interchange File Format (RIFF) specification developed by Microsoft and IBM. Structurally, a BWAVE file is composed of a number of chunks, each comprising a four character code chunk identifier, the chunk size, and the chunk data. It comprises a RIFF header with a WAVE data type identifier, followed by a series of chunks. Every file must include a Broadcast Audio Extension chunk, containing metadata required for exchange of information between broadcasters, a Format chunk, which describes the format of the audio data, and a Data chunk, containing the audio data itself. BWAVE files which contain MPEG-encoded audio data must also include a Fact chunk, containing file-dependent information about the audio data, and an MPEG Audio Extension chunk, containing extra information required to describe the MPEG encoding.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of New Zealand / National Library of New Zealand

details.dc:description: Broadcast WAVE is a chunk-based audio format developed by the European Broadcasting Union, and based on the Microsoft WAVE format, which is in turn based on the generic Resource Interchange File Format (RIFF) specification developed by Microsoft and IBM. Structurally, a BWAVE file is composed of a number of chunks, each comprising a four character code chunk identifier, the chunk size, and the chunk data. It comprises a RIFF header with a WAVE data type identifier, followed by a series of chunks. Every file must include a Broadcast Audio Extension chunk, containing metadata required for exchange of information between broadcasters, a Format chunk, which describes the format of the audio data, and a Data chunk, containing the audio data itself. BWAVE files which contain MPEG-encoded audio data must also include a Fact chunk, containing file-dependent information about the audio data, and an MPEG Audio Extension chunk, containing extra information required to describe the MPEG encoding.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of New Zealand / National Library of New Zealand

signature.name: RF64
signature.note: BOF: RF64{4}WAVEds64

details.dc:description: RF64 is a Broadcast Wave compatible multichannel file format enabling file sizes to exceed 4 GB. The file format is based on the Microsoft RIFF/WAVE format and Wave Format Extensible for multichannel parameters. Additions are made to the basic specification to allow for more than 4 GB file sizes when needed (the new maximum filesize is now approximately 16 exabytes).

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of New Zealand / National Library of New Zealand

signature.name: RF64 MBWF
signature.note: BOF: RF64{4}WAVEds64 with bext chunk following at indeterminate point. Further research is required to refine this signature

details.dc:description:
RF64 is a Broadcast Wave compatible multichannel file format enabling file sizes to exceed 4 GB. The file format is based on the Microsoft RIFF/WAVE format and Wave Format Extensible for multichannel parameters. Additions are made to the basic specification to allow for more than 4 GB file sizes when needed (the new maximum filesize is now approximately 16 exabytes).
An RF64 file containing the bext chunk becomes a Multichannel Broadcast Wave format. Further research is required to better understand this format. Users with samples are encouraged to contact the PRONOM team.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

details.dc:description:
MBOX is a commonly used format for storing email messages. MBOX files may be produced by a variety of email clients, however these are often not mutually compatible.
MBOX databases typically contain a linear sequence of electronic mail messages. Each message begins with a separator line that identifies the message sender, and also identifies the date and time at which the message was received by the final recipient (either the last-hop system in the transfer path, or the system which serves as the recipient's mailstore). Each message is typically terminated by an empty line. The end of the database is usually recognized by either the absence of any additional data, or by the presence of an explicit end-of-file marker.
Attachments within MBOX files are typically base 64 encoded, allowing binary data to be transferred over media designed to deal with textual data.
Due to the variety of MBOX structures, it is not currently possible to produce an authoritative signature for the format.

details.dc:description: KML is an Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC) sponsored xml schema file format used to display geographic data in an earth browser, such as Google Earth, Google Maps, and Google Maps for mobile. A KML file is processed in much the same way that HTML (and XML) files are processed by web browsers. Like HTML, KML has a tag-based structure with names and attributes used for specific display purposes. Thus, Google Earth and Maps act as browsers for KML files. Full specifications available at: http://www.opengeospatial.org/standards/kml
details.dc:creator: Google

signature.name: Dolby Digital AC-3
signature.note: The file consists of repeated frames of audio data. Each frame begins with the 0x0B77 syncword. The size of the frame is determined by the nominal bit rate and sample rate as per Table 5.18 of the Digital Audio Compression Standard specification http://www.atsc.org/cms/standards/a_52-2010.pdf

details.dc:description:
With the release of Word 97, Microsoft revised the native binary word processing format, which is based on its generic OLE2 Compound Document Format. A Word document is stored as a ‘WordDocument’ stream within a Compound Document Format file. The format remained unchanged with the releases of Word 2000, 2002 and 2003. An alternative extension of .wbk refers to a backup file of a Word document, however there is no material or structural difference between a .wbk file and the .doc file it is a backup of.
Within the 'WordDocument' stream, the byte at position 0x0B deals with encryption/obfuscation, as per the MS FibBase description page - https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd944620(v=office.12).aspx. The first bit (Least Significant Bit (LSB) ordering) specifies whether the file is encrypted, meaning that if the byte at 0x0B is an 'odd' byte (e.g. 01, 03, 05, 07, 09, 0B, 0D, 0F, 11, 13 etc.) then this indicates obfuscation/encryption is present.
details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

record_metadata.dc:creator: Archives New Zealand / Archives New Zealand
record_metadata.dc:description: This format can be identified via a container signature in DROID version 6 or later. The PRONOM database cannot currently represent container signatures.

Within the 'WordDocument' stream, the byte at position 0x0B deals with encryption/obfuscation, as per the MS FibBase description page - https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd944620(v=office.12).aspx. The first bit (Least Significant Bit (LSB) ordering) specifies whether the file is encrypted, meaning that if the byte at 0x0B is an 'odd' byte (e.g. 01, 03, 05, 07, 09, 0B, 0D, 0F, 11, 13 etc.) then this indicates obfuscation/encryption is present.

signature.name: SWF 11 - zlib compressed
signature.note: Header (CWS then version number)

details.dc:description: The Adobe Flash format, SWF, previously known as Shockwave Flash or Macromedia Shockwave Flash, and alternatively known as the Small Web Format, is a file format primarily designed for creating interactive multimedia applications. The format iterates rapidly, often in line with new releases of Adobe Flash or Adobe Air. Prior to version 6 all SWF files were uncompressed, however version 6 introduced the option of using zlib compression. Version 13 introduced the option of using LZMA compression.
details.dc:creator: Adobe Systems Incorporated

details.dc:description: The Adobe Flash format, SWF, previously known as Shockwave Flash or Macromedia Shockwave Flash, and alternatively known as the Small Web Format, is a file format primarily designed for creating interactive multimedia applications. The format iterates rapidly, often in line with new releases of Adobe Flash or Adobe Air. Prior to version 6 all SWF files were uncompressed, however version 6 introduced the option of using zlib compression. Version 13 introduced the option of using LZMA compression.
details.dc:creator: Adobe Systems Incorporated

signature.note: 0xa1b2c3d4 indicates that the capture reader has the same byte order as the capture writer. 0xd4c3b2a1 indicates that the reader has a different byte order from the writer.

signature.name: PowerVR POD
signature.note: Format consists of blocks. Identification based upon 'version' block - 8 bytes 'version' block start tag: identifier = 0xE8030000 & length of block (11 bytes = 0x0B000000) - Data (in this case the 11 byte null-terminated version string AB.POD.2.0) - 8 bytes 'version' block end tag: identifier = 0xE8030080 & length (0 bytes as end tag = 0x00000000)

details.dc:description: The PowerVR Object Data format is a 3D modelling format developed by Imagination Technologies.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: MXF OP1b
signature.note: Header ..+4.......... then Operational Pattern Label ..+4..........

details.dc:description:
MXF is a media container format which supports a number of different streams of coded "essence", encoded with any of a variety of codecs, together with a metadata wrapper which describes the material contained within the MXF file.
MXF allows for different degrees of complexity within the wrapper, which are standardised and defined as Operational Patterns, and this may be a consideration for an institution considering preserving the format, hence the separation of these Operational Patterns into separate PUIDs.
OP1b is intended to meet the requirements of acquisition, storage and interchange applications where more than one essence component is required and it is wished to carry these in two or more essence containers.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: MXF OP1c
signature.note: Header ..+4.......... then Operational Pattern Label ..+4..........

details.dc:description:
MXF is a media container format which supports a number of different streams of coded "essence", encoded with any of a variety of codecs, together with a metadata wrapper which describes the material contained within the MXF file.
MXF allows for different degrees of complexity within the wrapper, which are standardised and defined as Operational Patterns, and this may be a consideration for an institution considering preserving the format, hence the separation of these Operational Patterns into separate PUIDs.
OP1c: A choice of 2 or more alternate material packages that play out selected tracks of either a single file package or two or more synchronized file packages.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: MXF OP2a
signature.note: Header ..+4.......... then Operational Pattern Label ..+4..........

details.dc:description:
MXF is a media container format which supports a number of different streams of coded "essence", encoded with any of a variety of codecs, together with a metadata wrapper which describes the material contained within the MXF file.
MXF allows for different degrees of complexity within the wrapper, which are standardised and defined as Operational Patterns, and this may be a consideration for an institution considering preserving the format, hence the separation of these Operational Patterns into separate PUIDs.
OP2a is intended to meet the requirements of acquisition, storage and interchange applications that are satisfied by a play-list of individual items of content packaged in two or more essence containers each of the same type.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: MXF OP2b
signature.note: Header ..+4.......... then Operational Pattern Label ..+4..........

details.dc:description:
MXF is a media container format which supports a number of different streams of coded "essence", encoded with any of a variety of codecs, together with a metadata wrapper which describes the material contained within the MXF file.
MXF allows for different degrees of complexity within the wrapper, which are standardised and defined as Operational Patterns, and this may be a consideration for an institution considering preserving the format, hence the separation of these Operational Patterns into separate PUIDs.
OP2b is intended to meet the requirements of acquisition, storage and interchange applications where more than one essence component is required and it is wished to carry these in four or more essence containers.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: MXF OP2c
signature.note: Header ..+4.......... then Operational Pattern Label ..+4..........

details.dc:description:
MXF is a media container format which supports a number of different streams of coded "essence", encoded with any of a variety of codecs, together with a metadata wrapper which describes the material contained within the MXF file.
MXF allows for different degrees of complexity within the wrapper, which are standardised and defined as Operational Patterns, and this may be a consideration for an institution considering preserving the format, hence the separation of these Operational Patterns into separate PUIDs.
OP2c: A choice of 2 or more alternate material packages that play out selected tracks of either a sequence of single file packages, or a sequence of two or more synchronized file packages.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: MXF OP3a
signature.note: Header ..+4.......... then Operational Pattern Label ..+4..........

details.dc:description:
MXF is a media container format which supports a number of different streams of coded "essence", encoded with any of a variety of codecs, together with a metadata wrapper which describes the material contained within the MXF file.
MXF allows for different degrees of complexity within the wrapper, which are standardised and defined as Operational Patterns, and this may be a consideration for an institution considering preserving the format, hence the separation of these Operational Patterns into separate PUIDs.
OP3a: A material package that plays out an edit list from one or more file packages where only a single file package may be referenced at any given position on any material package timeline.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: MXF OP3b
signature.note: Header ..+4.......... then Operational Pattern Label ..+4..........

details.dc:description:
MXF is a media container format which supports a number of different streams of coded "essence", encoded with any of a variety of codecs, together with a metadata wrapper which describes the material contained within the MXF file.
MXF allows for different degrees of complexity within the wrapper, which are standardised and defined as Operational Patterns, and this may be a consideration for an institution considering preserving the format, hence the separation of these Operational Patterns into separate PUIDs.
OP3b: A material package that plays out an edit list from two or more file packages each of which may be referenced and synchronized at any given position along the material package timeline.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: MXF OP3c
signature.note: Header ..+4.......... then Operational Pattern Label ..+4..........

details.dc:description:
MXF is a media container format which supports a number of different streams of coded "essence", encoded with any of a variety of codecs, together with a metadata wrapper which describes the material contained within the MXF file.
MXF allows for different degrees of complexity within the wrapper, which are standardised and defined as Operational Patterns, and this may be a consideration for an institution considering preserving the format, hence the separation of these Operational Patterns into separate PUIDs.
OP3c: A choice of 2 or more alternate material packages that play out selected portions of tracks (edit list) from one or more file packages each of which may be referenced and synchronized at any given position along the timeline.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: MXF OP-ATOM
signature.note: Header ..+4.......... then Operational Pattern Label ..+4.........

details.dc:description:
MXF is a media container format which supports a number of different streams of coded "essence", encoded with any of a variety of codecs, together with a metadata wrapper which describes the material contained within the MXF file.
MXF allows for different degrees of complexity within the wrapper, which are standardised and defined as Operational Patterns, and this may be a consideration for an institution considering preserving the format, hence the separation of these Operational Patterns into separate PUIDs.
Operational Pattern “OP-Atom” is intended to satisfy the demands of applications where there is a requirement for exchange of material and associated metadata together in a single file with an open and standardized format, yet also a demand for a simple, predictable, layout with minimum scope for variation. OP-Atom is specifically intended for applications where each Essence Track is held separately.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: UEF
signature.note: Header - UEF File!.

details.dc:description: The Unified Emulator Format (UEF) was developed by Thomas Harte and is a format that is used to store audio tapes, ROMs, floppy discs and machine state snapshots for the 8-bit range of computers manufactured by Acorn Computers. UEF files can be created using an application called MakeUEF which converts audio samples into UEF files, MakeUEF claims to be the sole creator of UEF files available on websites prior to November 2004. From version 1.0 of MakeUEF the fidelity of the software was improved and an additional extension of .hq.uef (meaning high quality) was adopted for these files.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: RPMv1
signature.note: header - í«îÛ.

details.dc:description: RPM Package Manager file (RPM) was previously known as a Red Hat Package Manager File. It is a file used by RPM Package Manager which is a package management system. RPM files currently appear in two defined types, the first is binary package files containing the compiled version of certain software. The second is source package files containing the source code used to produce a package. These have an appropriate tag in the file header that distinguishes them from Binary RPMs, causing them to be extracted to /usr/src on installation. Source package files customarily carry the file extension “.src.rpm".

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

format.name: Encase Image File Format/Expert Witness Compression Format

signature.name: EO1
signature.note: Header - EVF...ÿ.

details.dc:description: Expert Witness was the original name for EnCase, as such this format can be referred to as either Expert Witness Compression Format or Encase Image File Format. The format is used to store media images for forensic purposes. They are a type of disk image containing the contents and structure of an entire data storage device, disk volume or even a computer's physical memory. This format creates segments which have different file extensions, the first will have the extension '.e01'. this increases first numerically upto '.e99' the next extension will be '.eaa' increasing to an estimated limit of '.zzz'.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: L01
signature.note: Header - LVF...ÿ.

details.dc:description: Logical FIle Evidence Format was introduced in EnCase version 5. They are form of Encase Image files, this format is used to store media images for forensic purposes. They are a type of disk image containing the contents and structure of an entire data storage device, disk volume or even a computer's physical memory. The logical version of this format is used to create an image of the original files as they existed on the media but also documents other ifnormation. This includes the assigned file name and extension, datetime of creation, modified date, and date last accessed, the logical and physical size, an MD5 hash value, permissions and original path. This format creates segments which have different file extensions, the first will have the extension '.l01'. this increases first numerically upto '.l99' the next extension will be '.laa' increasing to an estimated limit of '.zzz'.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

details.dc:description: JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) is an open standard format that uses human-readable text to transmit data objects consisting of attribute–value pairs. It is used for asynchronous browser/server communication (AJAJ). While it is originally derived from JavaScript scripting language, JSON is language independent while using conventions that match with the C-family of languages, including C, C++, C#, Java, JavaScript, Perl, Python, and others.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: CDXA
signature.note: BOF: RIFF{4}CDXA

details.dc:description: CD-ROM XA (Compact Disc - read-only-memory, extended architecture) is a modification of CD-ROM that defines sectors that enable it to read and display data, graphics, video, and audio. Photo CD, Video CD, CD-EXTRA and Super Video CD have all been based on CDXA and it may be possible to further distinguish between these different CDXA variant formats with further PRONOM research.

details.dc:description: P00 is a Commodore 64 emulation format created for use with the PC64 emulator. The extension is normally 'Pxx', where the xx represents a two digit number corresponding to an incremented extension (beginning with P00) where more than one otherwise identically named P00 file exists in a single directory. For example, five files each called 'file' in a single dircetory would have the extensions p00, p01, p02, p03 and p04.

signature.name: AD1
signature.note: BOF: ADSEGMENTEDFILE. A single AD1 file, or the first part of a multipart AD1 will also contain the string ADLOGICALIMAGE, likely at position 0x0200

details.dc:description:
The AccessData Custom Content Image (AD1) file format is a file-level disk image format created by AccessData's proprietary forensic software, such as FTK Imager.
An AD1 image may span multiple files, with multipart files distinguished by their incrementing file extension, e.g. .ad1, .ad2, .ad3, etc.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Artefactual Systems Inc / Artefactual Systems Inc

signature.name: AD1 (encrypted)
signature.note: BOF: ADCRYPT

details.dc:description:
The AccessData Custom Content Image (AD1) file format is a file-level disk image format created by AccessData's proprietary forensic software, such as FTK Imager.
AD1 images may be encrypted or unencrypted. Encrypted images have only a small unencrypted chunk at the beginning of the file, beginning with the magic bytes "ADCRYPT" at byte 0.

signature.name: 3DM 5
signature.note: Header with version number - 3D Geometry File Format 5

details.dc:description: The 3DM (openNURBS) format is a 3D model representation based on non-uniform rational B-Splines (NURBS). The file format is defined by an open source C++ toolkit that reads and writes openNURBS models.
details.dc:creator: Robert McNeel & Associates

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Canadian Centre for Architecture / The Canadian Centre for Architecture

details.dc:description:
STL is a 3D modelling file format created by 3D Systems. An STL file is a triangular representation of a 3-dimensional surface geometry. The surface is tessellated or broken down logically into a series of small triangles (facets). Each facet is described by a perpendicular direction and three points representing the vertices (corners) of the triangle. These data are used by a slicing algorithm to determine the cross sections of the 3-dimensional shape to be built by the fabricator.
The structure of STL Binary, though well defined, makes it impossible to create an identification signature under the current PRONOM signature model.
The format consists of an 80 byte ASCII header with no formalized structure, followed by a four byte integer value representing the number of facets within the file, followed by 48 bytes of floating point values representing the 'normal' and 'vertex' coordinates within 3 dimensional space for each triangle, followed by a two byte, typically (but not exclusively) unused 'attribute byte count'.
A technical specification may be found here: http://www.fabbers.com/tech/STL_Format

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Canadian Centre for Architecture / The Canadian Centre for Architecture

details.dc:description:
These files may be produced by saving a web page in various versions of Apple's Safari Web Browser. The file is a type of Binary Property List (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Property_list) and will contain the html content of the page, plus any page attachments.
With further research and a better understanding of the format it may be possible to create a PRONOM identification signature, based on the 'bplist' magic number and further identifiers specific to the Apple Safari Webarchive format.
details.dc:creator: Apple Computer, Inc.

details.dc:description: Every MySQL table is represented on disk by a .frm file that describes the table's format (that is, the table definition). The file bears the same name as the table, with an .frm extension.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Artefactual Systems Inc / Artefactual Systems Inc

signature.name: CDX Archive Index
signature.note: BOF: <field delimiter (usually space)>CDX<field delimiter (usually space)>, followed by CDX options as described here: https://archive.org/web/researcher/cdx_file_format.php For signature strength we currently assume the field delimiter will be a space character (hex 0x20) rather than a wildcard, with scope to add further delimiters as they are encountered.

details.dc:description: A CDX file consists of individual lines of text, each of which summarizes a single web document. The first line in the file is a legend for interpreting the data, and the following lines contain the data for referencing the corresponding pages within the host. The first character of the file is the field delimiter used in the rest of the file. This is followed by the literal "CDX". For signature strength we currently assume the field delimiter will be a space character, however please contact the PRONOM team should you encounter CDX index files where the delimiter is different.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

details.dc:description: This is a script written in Perl that is composed and run using a Perl interpreter; it contains lines of Perl program code with variables, operations, functions, and comments.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: Adobe Content Server Message

details.dc:description: Adobe Content Server Message files are used to manage and download digital content, mostly ebooks, via Adobe Digital Editions. The .acsm file is essentially a 'key' to allow the download of purchased content.
details.dc:creator: Adobe Systems Incorporated

record_metadata.dc:creator: British Library / British Library

signature.name: FLIF
signature.note: BOF: 4 byte Magic string: 'FLIF', 1 byte Type string: 1 = static, grayscale, non-interlaced; 3 = static, RGB, non-interlaced; 4 = static, RGBA, non-interlaced; A = static, grayscale; C = static, RGB, interlaced; D = static, RGBA, interlaced; Q = animated, grayscale, non-interlaced; S = animated, RGB, non-interlaced; T = animated, RGBA, non-interlaced; a = animated, grayscale; c = animated, RGB, interlaced; d = animated, RGBA, interlaced.

details.dc:description: FLIF is a lossless image format, developed by Jon Sneyers. FLIF is based on MANIAC compression. MANIAC (Meta-Adaptive Near-zero Integer Arithmetic Coding) is a variant of CABAC (context-adaptive binary arithmetic coding), where the contexts are nodes of decision trees which are dynamically learned at encode time.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

details.dc:description: Notation3, or N3, is a shorthand non-XML serialization of Resource Description Framework models.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

details.dc:description: Turtle (Terse RDF Triple Language) is a format for expressing data in the Resource Description Framework (RDF) data model.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

details.dc:description: RDF/XML is a syntax, defined by the W3C, to express (i.e. serialize) an RDF (Resource Description Framework) graph as an XML document.
details.dc:creator: W3C / W3C

details.dc:creator: IBM Corporation

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

details.dc:description: JSON-LD is a JSON-based format to serialize Linked Data. It is designed to be easy to convert an existing JSON file to JSON-LD. It's main objective is to be a way to use Linked Data in Web-based programming environments, to build interoperable Web services, and to store Linked Data in JSON-based storage engines.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: Microsoft Document Imaging File Format
signature.note: EP*.

details.dc:description: This is a proprietary file format created by Microsoft Document Imaging, a program which enables the editing and annotation of documents scanned by Microsoft Office Document Scanning. It was introduced in Office XP and was included in Office 2003 and 2007. This format is a variant of TIFF.
details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

details.dc:creator: MicroPro Inc

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

details.dc:description: This is a compound version of Wordperfect for Windows. Also known as Corel WordPerfect. Major and minor version fields are the main variants between 6.x and 12 formats (The last two bytes in this signature). The major version is the same for 6.x through to 12 documents - 2. The minor version byte for a non-compound file created in WPWin 8.0 is 1. The minor version for a compound file created in WPWin 8.0. Is 2.

signature.name: Gaussian Input Data File
signature.note: #*(AM1|PM3|STO-3G|3-21G|3-21g|6-31G|6-31g|augcc-pvtz){0-128}.{0-128}.(-1|2|0)( |,)[0:9]{0-128}[0:9].[0:9]{0-24}[0:9].[0:9]{0-24}[0:9].[0:9] This signature has been developed with reference to the basic structure of Gaussian input files as described: http://www.gaussian.com/g_tech/g_ur/m_input.htm and http://chemistry.umeche.maine.edu/Modeling/GGGauss.html. The 'Route Section' describes the 'Basis Set' used, as listed here: http://www.gaussian.com/g_tech/g_ur/m_basis_sets.htm. The current signature includes the basis sets AM1,PM3,STO-3G,3-21G,3-21g,6-31G,6-31g and augcc-pvtz. It is likely that additional basis sets have been used in this format, if this has been perceived then please feed this back to PRONOM so the signature can be improved.

details.dc:description: Gaussian Input Data files are created by the Gaussian computer program for computational chemistry.

signature.name: Zoomify ZIF
signature.note: BOF: II+..... https://github.com/lovasoa/ZIF/

details.dc:description: Zoomify offers the ability to zoom into high resolution images. It works by converting a high resolution image into a collection of JPEG tiles that are stored within a .zif file. This file can in turn be displayed within a web browser with the aid of a javascript library.

details.dc:description: The mapsforge project aims to provide free and open software for the rendering of maps based on OpenStreetMap data. The Binary Map File Format is designed for map rendering on devices with limited resources, such as mobile phones.

signature.name: APNG
signature.note: Signature + IHDR and acTL chunks at BOF, IEND chunk at EOF Specification: https://wiki.mozilla.org/APNG_Specification

details.dc:description:
APNG is an extension of the PNG format, adding support for animated images. It is intended to be a replacement for simple animated images that have traditionally used the GIF format, while adding support for 24-bit images and 8-bit transparency. APNG is intended as a simpler alternative to MNG.
APNG is backwards-compatible with PNG; any PNG decoder should be able to ignore the APNG-specific chunks and display a single image.

signature.name: Ogg Container
signature.note: Capture pattern (“OggS”); stream structure revision (00h); flag: 1st page of a logical bitstream (02h)

details.dc:description:
Ogg is a free, open container format maintained by the Xiph.Org Foundation. The Ogg container format can multiplex a number of independent streams for audio, video, text, and metadata.
In the Ogg multimedia framework, Theora provides a lossy video layer. The audio layer is commonly provided by the music-oriented Vorbis format. Other audio coding format options include the Opus compression format, the lossless audio compression format FLAC, Speex for low bitrate voice data, and OggPCM for uncompressed PCM audio.
This generic entry applies where available PRONOM signatures for Ogg do not yet apply to the file in question. In this instance you may wish to contact pronom@nationalarchives.gov.uk to help improve PRONOM's signatures.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

details.dc:description:
WordPerfect is a Word Processing application currently owned by Corel Corporation. The original version of WordPerfect 4.0 was released in 1984. 4.1 followed in 1985 and 4.2 in 1986, with versions released on various platforms up to 1988 when version 5.0 was originally released for DOS.
Only the technical specification for version 4.2 is currently known to have been made public, originally via the PC Developer's Toolkit diskette, and this can be found preserved here: http://www.columbia.edu/~em36/wpdos/wp42ff.txt.
The file format for the WP4.2 version contains only the document body with special function codes, and the format lacks a header or mandatory elements that can be used by PRONOM for automatic identification. Each function code represents a text function, such as bold or underline, so with reference to the specification it should be possible to parse the file to understand the intended layout. It may be the case that the file format for 4.0 and 4.1 is functionally identical or very similar to version 4.2.
A free C++ library called libwpd is available: http://libwpd.sourceforge.net/ and it includes the ability to parse WP4.2 files. This library is known to have been implemented in LibreOffice, Koffice, and AbiWord among others, so these applications can be used to open and render WordPerfect 4.2 files, and potentially WP4.0 and WP4.1.
Due to the age of the format, WP4.x files may lack a format extension, however .wp4 and .wpd are known to be associated with the format.
details.dc:creator: Corel Corporation

details.dc:description: Adaptive Multi-Rate Wideband (AMR-WB) is a wideband speech audio coding standard based on Adaptive Multi-Rate encoding. AMR-WB provides a speech bandwidth of 50–7000 Hz compared to narrowband speech coders which in general offer around 300–3400 Hz. AMR-WB was developed by Nokia and VoiceAge.

details.dc:description: The DirectMusic Segment is a file format created by Microsoft. SGT files contain playing order and track information. Segment files always come with DirectMusic Style files, which contain all required melody pattern information.

signature.name: Portable Sound Format
signature.note:
BOF: PSFx, where x represents one of the following values for which PSF has been adapted
4th byte: 0x01: Playstation (PSF1) 0x02: Playstation 2 (PSF2) 0x11: Sega Saturn (SSF) 0x12: Sega Dreamcast (DSF) 0x13: Sega Genesis 0x21: Nintendo 64 (USF) 0x22: GameBoy Advance (GSF) 0x23: Super NES (SNSF) 0x41: Capcom QSound (QSF)
Format description: http://web.archive.org/web/20140125155137/http://wiki.neillcorlett.com/PSFFormat

details.dc:description: The Portable Sound Format (PSF) is a sequencer sound file format for video game music, created by Neill Corlett. PSF files contain audio data and a sequence player. A file with the .psf or .psf1 extensions will usually be self-contained files holding both the audio library data and sequencing data. A .minipsf or .minipsf1 will hold just sequencing data, while a .psflib or .psf1lib will contain the audio library data so these must reside in the same directory where used.

details.dc:description: XMF is a family of specifications created and administered by the MIDI Manufacturer's Association. An XMF file contains one or more existing files such as Standard MIDI Files, Downloadable Sound (DLS) instrument files, WAV files, or other digital audio files to create a collection of all the resources needed to present a musical piece. Mobile XMF was developed specifically for mobile phones, and supports SP-MIDI format SMF files as well as Mobile DLS content.

details.dc:description:
The Music Encoding Initiative (MEI) is an open-source effort to define a system for encoding musical documents in a machine-readable structure. MEI is formalised in the MEI schema, a core set of rules for recording physical and intellectual characteristics of music notation documents expressed as an eXtensible Markup Language (XML) schema.
PRONOM currently does not distinguish between different versions of MEI.

signature.name: Apple Double Resource Fork (v1)
signature.note: BOF: 4 byte AppleDouble Magic Number 0x00051607, then 4 byte version number 0x00010000

details.dc:description:
The resource fork is a construct of the Mac OS operating system used to store structured data in a file, alongside unstructured data stored within the data fork. The format specification is available here: http://support.apple.com/kb/TA32537?viewlocale=en_US
The format lacks an extension, and is instead represented by a file name consisting of ._<filename resource fork belongs to>
details.dc:creator: Apple Computer, Inc.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: AppleSingle v1
signature.note: BOF: 4 byte AppleSingle Magic Number 0x00051600, then 4 byte version number 0x00010000

details.dc:description: Apple Computers created the AppleSingle format (as well as the AppleDouble format) to represent and preserve the attributes of files across files systems that do not support the same attributes of the file’s home systems. AppleSingle is primarily a storage format and contains both a file’s contents and attributes. It consists of a header and one or more optional data entries followed by the byte stream of the file it is storing. It maintains the original Macintosh filename and file type (e.g. Mydoc.pdf). The AppleSingle format can store a number of different kinds of formats.
details.dc:creator: Apple Computer, Inc.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: RTF 0
signature.note: BOF: {\rtf0 version control word & any character set control word from /ansi /mac /pc /pca

details.dc:description:
Rich Text Format (RTF) is a format developed by Microsoft to encode formatted text and graphics for use within applications or for data and formatting transfer between applications. It is closely associated with Microsoft Word, and new versions are developed with each release of Word. RTF files are encoded in plain text, typically ASCII, and consists of a series of control words, control symbols and groups. An RTF file comprises a Header section, containing various header tables, followed by a Document section, containing the document content and formatting.
RTF0 may predate version 1.0 of the RTF specification which is known to date from at least 1992. Please contact the PRONOM team if you are aware of or have access to a formal specification for RTF0.
details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

details.dc:description: In the OS X, iOS, NeXTSTEP, and GNUstep programming frameworks, property list files store serialized objects. It is the standard way to save and load data between the internal representation within the objects defined in an Objective-C program and disk files, in order to store program settings and other data. This is the XML version but there is also a binary version of the format.
